content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 9 ยง 4.112 - Executive order no. 112: establishing the new york state christopher columbus quincentenary commission

State Regulations
WHEREAS, October 12, 1992, marks the five hundredth
anniversary of the voyages of discovery of Christopher Columbus; WHEREAS, Columbus' joining of the New World and the Old
began the modern era of human history; WHEREAS, all persons in this State should look with pride
on the achievements and contributions of their ancestors with respect to those
historic voyages; WHEREAS, the governments and people of Spain and Italy
should be recognized and commended for their historic role and contributions to
those voyages; WHEREAS, it is appropriate to celebrate and commemorate
this anniversary through local and statewide observances; WHEREAS, it is important that the observance of the
anniversary balance the goals of ceremony and celebration with scholarship and
education; WHEREAS, it is appropriate that the State of New York joins
the peoples of Spain, Italy and the Americas in observing the quincentenary in
honor of Columbus, in recognition of our common heritage, and as a reminder of
the history on which our accomplishments are based; NOW, THEREFORE, I, MARIO M. CUOMO, Governor of the State of

New York, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and Laws
of the State of New York, do hereby order as follows: I. New York State Christopher Columbus

Quincentenary Commission

There is hereby created a commission to be known as the New

York State Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Commission. The members of the
commission shall be appointed by the Governor and shall serve at the pleasure
of the Governor. Commission members shall be broadly representative of the
people of the State of New York. One of the members shall be designated as

Chairman by, and shall serve in the position of Chairman at the pleasure of, the Governor. The Governor's Office of Special Projects and Protocol
shall serve as the coordinating agency for the commission and the director of
such office shall serve as the director and an ex officio member of the
commission. In carrying out the duties of the commission, the director shall
consult with appropriate State officials, including the executive director of
the Governor' s Office of Hispanic Affairs and the assistant to the Governor
for Ethnic Relations. Members shall receive no compensation, but shall be
entitled to reasonable reimbursement for any necessary expenses incurred in
connection with the performance of their duties. II. Purposes and Responsibilities of the

Commission

The commission shall: 1. plan and develop activities to commemorate
the quincentennial of the voyages of Christopher Columbus, including a limited
number of projects to be undertaken by the State, seeking to harmonize and
balance the important goals of ceremony and celebration with the equally
important goals of scholarship and education; 2. encourage and promote private
organizations and local governments, to organize and participate in
quincentennial activities commemorating and examining the historic events
associated with those voyages; 3. serve as a clearinghouse for the collection and dissemination of information
about quincentennial events and plans in the State; 4. cooperate and coordinate with the national

Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Jubilee Commission in preparing a
comprehensive plan of commemoration to suit the national celebration, including
the Grand Columbus Regatta which will occur on July 4, 1992 in New York Harbor; and
5. seek the cooperation, advice
and assistance from both private and governmental agencies and organizations, including local governments, learned societies, academic institutions and
historical, patriotic, philanthropic, civic, and professional groups, and bar
associations. III. Assistance

Whenever possible, the Commission shall make use of
existing staff and resources in the various State agencies, which are hereby
directed to render full cooperation and assistance to the commission. Signed: Mario M. CuomoDated: September 22, 1988
